content.description: Lieback the flake to the hand crack. Exiting the crack is the crux.
content.location:
It is where

Thin Wires

used to be.

content.description:
Climb the left-facing crack past a small roof, then continue to a ledge and a tree anchor.

Per

knowbuddy Buddy

: Thin Wires has fallen exposing a hand crack called

Wally World

.
content.location:
This is on the left hand side of the

Bedrock

area.

content.description: Start up a face with some cracks for gear to reach some bolts.  Then follow chickenheads to the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts plus a light rack - #3 Camalot.
content.location:
This route starts at the right side of

Bedrock

.  Look for the bolts on the middle part of the route.

content.description: Follow the slab to the chimney/crack. Follow this through the small roof, more chimney to the anchor. Watch for some loose rock, otherwise a fun long climb.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a #4 Camalot.
content.location:
It is in between

Betty

and

Barney's Crack

. Rappel the route from two bolt anchor. It is easier to rappel down

Betty

rather than down The Squeeze due to the potential for your rope getting stuck.

content.description: This is a wide crack, and it has bat shit!!!
content.protection:
Pretty wide stuff.

Per

e Dixon

: there are 2 bolts for an anchor.
content.location:
It is the obvious crack to the left of

Betty

.

content.description:
P1 - Start up the same crack as

Betty

, once at the roof move right and traverse across

Stoneage Struggle

to a hanging belay.

P2 - Climb up and left and finish the same as

Stoneage Struggle

.

Descent - One rappel with a 60m rope back to the ground.
content.protection: Standard rack, gear can be a little tricky.
content.location:
Same start as

Betty

, just left of

Stoneage Struggle

.

content.description:
This is a direct start to

Betty

that climbs the slab between the two cracks and links up to

Betty's

second bolt. Climb the slab, and figure out how to get onto the pedestal for a no hands rest. The crux starts after leaving the pedestal.

Ascend steep face climbing past bolts, then follow a steep thin crack up to another bolt and the anchor.  This route used to be 5.12c, but over time holds have broken off making it much harder.

See the comment below.
content.location:
Left of

Gorilla Crack

, this finger crack is easy to spot.

content.description: Climb past an awkward overhanging start to get into the wide crack.  Offwidth/lieback your way up to an intermediate ledge (tree with slings). Continue past some loose blocks and up varied crack climbing to another tree with slings at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Standard East A rack plus #4, #5, #6 Camalots.
content.location:
This is on the far left side of the

Bedrock

area.  The wide crack is fairly obvious. Start off a large boulder at the base.

content.description:
Start up an easy handcrack with a tree growing out of it.  Follow the crack as it thins up into a right-facing corner below a roof.  Move left and up with some fun moves and follow the slab to an anchor shared with

The Squeeze

.
content.location:
It is left of

Stoneage Struggle

and just right of

The Squeeze

.

content.description: This is a great route and an East A classic! Technical and difficult moves up a slab past the first three bolts leads to varied, interesting, and somewhat awkward face climbing protected by four more bolts. Fire up the nice steep and pumpy finger crack plugging in gear, clip one last bolt and mantle to a small ledge with bolts and chains.
content.protection: Blue - yellow Aliens, small - medium stoppers, 8 bolts.
content.location:
This is between

Gorilla Crack

and

The Squeeze

.

content.description:
Bam Bam is a truly outstanding route that climbs a clean, gently overhanging face on the best rock East A. has to offer. For Durango standards, this is difficult face climbing at its finest! The route breaks down into two distinct sections: the mellow first half of fun and technical 5.12- climbing on vertical rock; and the brutal and desperate second half where the angle kicks back and the climbing is full on till you clip the chains.

Between bolt #3 and #4, one could bypass some difficulty by following a crack out right then traversing back left on slopers. Resist the urge, and stay true to the line, the climbing is fun and the rock is fantastic.

It should be noted that I did not bolt this line. It is an old project originally equipped long before I moved to DGO, I believe by Joel? Given the quality of the line and the strong group of climbers that frequent East A, I am blown away that it has not seen more attention. Hopefully this post will get people psyched!
content.protection: 9 bolts, many of which need to be extended to ease rope drag and clipping, and fixed anchors.
content.location:
This ascends the beautiful face just left of

Barney's Crack

.
